column11: Sexual/Domestic Violence and Identifying Workplace Harassment, Comprehensive Mental Health Awareness, Assessments & Resources, Comprehensive Sex Education beyond basic reproduction (safe sex, consent, pleasure, desire), Conversations on Gender Identity & Sexuality, Normalization & Destigmatization of Menstruation, Financial Planning (basic concepts), Understanding Socio-Political landscape, Comprehensive understanding of Cyber Etiquettes, Crimes, Laws
column31: There were sessions held on good touch and bad touch at a very impressionable age which was much needed but yet it stopped once we reached 8th grade. How mental health affects children was never discussed, it was never given importance. Till date making sure girls were covered and wore clothes which never went above the knee length is given utmost importance in our school. Though there was no discrimination in terms of sports, there was always women empowerment. Having studied in a religious school, talks of gender identity was never considered to have a differing opinion. Financial planning was never discussed. our history teacher always discussed the socio-political stance of different countries and our history so that was commendable
column32: It will definitely make a difference

column31:
Most faculty at school, turned a blind eye to it and the ones who did care, seemed very cynical about the situation. “What can we do” - it’s a big institution and they don’t have the authority for taking certain actions. 
Jokes : VERY controversial and important, what is considered a joke? What is offensive and when do you draw the line? 
But this won’t happen through teaching so again, changing the mentality of students from a young age which is always tough because the teacher has to believe in it enough to convey it to the students.
LOT of discrimination in sports.
column32: It will definitely make a difference
column33:
Really hope you take this forward; it’s so important and we really need this. 

But again, when trustees or principals are narrow minded and can’t comprehend the idea of simple things such as basic quality between genders - how is it going to be possible to introduce these modules into the education system? First the mindset of the faculty must change and they will have to go through extensive training.

column31: I changed schools after grade 8. I was appointed sports captain of the school in class 12. I wanted to create a girl's football team because I knew there were a lot of girls who were keen to play and many with brilliant accolades. For example many of the girls had played at national and international levels. These qualifications only made it more important for the school to have a team for girls. But all the training, effort and appreciation went for the boys team. When I addressed this, no one was keen, neither the teachers nor the rest of the council members. In fact the other sports captain (boys) who was part of the boys football team went on to say that the girls are no interested why should the coach waste their time on them. It was really disappointing.
column32: It will definitely make a difference

As much as they did try to embrace the ‘co-ed culture’, they were wary about it too. Even something as basic as teaching boys and girls things like menstruation were conducted separately, which is where i think the Indian education system falters, not just at my ‘alma mater’, but everywhere else too.

column31:
Some of these topics were most definitely overlooked and not put on a pedestal which I feel is incorrect. The environment isn’t liberal or open enough to discuss how to tackle these issues which is why a lot of times students in crises are helpless, as schools don’t consider the issues important. These students often feel neglected as their personal issues aren’t deemed to be “of utmost importance”. 
For a lot of the other issues, schools tend to avoid addressing them on grounds of them being “controversial”. They dissuade students from voicing their opinion out of fear that the topic is too “sensitive” and creates unnecessary “buzz”.
column32: It will definitely make a difference
column33: It’ll be wonderful if the education system can revamp it’s approach towards teaching students. It shouldn’t discriminate between pressing issues as “too sensitive, too controversial, too touchy”. Rather they should equip students with the ability to recognise the importance and relevance of these issues to our future.

column11: Sexual/Domestic Violence and Identifying Workplace Harassment, Conversations on Gender Identity & Sexuality, Financial Planning (basic concepts), Understanding Socio-Political landscape
column31: I think some teachers were pretty old school and didn't like acknowledging things. I know of a few people holding positions of authority shaming girls for looking a certain way or wearing a certain things or speaking a certain way. Staff room gossip is real. Other than that in most (if not all) cases of sexual harassment, the boy was often let go without any social or disciplinary repercussions while the girl always faced social and sometimes even disciplinary repercussions. In one of the cases of sexual intimacy (it was consensual but happened on school property) the girl faced SEVERE repercussions while the boy got away with it.
column32: It could make a difference
column33: I dont think kids take these kinds of seminars seriously. I know that when i was a kid I didn't, the anti-bullying assembly used to be an excuse to miss classes for us and we wouldn't really care, even though the school really tried to engage with us. There was an integrated period to address such topics at some point in time in our class timetables, it was considered to be a free period/ fun time. So i don't know how a difference could be made to be honest.

column31: I guess schools have certain rules and regulations which should be followed. If anyone does not obey them, then they should be approached irrespective of their gender. My school believed in equality of gender so both guys as well as girls were told to obey the rules and one shouldn't feel bad because of this. Just how a workplace has a dress-code, so do schools. I don't understand why is it so hard for people to follow it.
column32: It could make a difference
column33: Schools should pay more attention to these types of topics and conversations as they're equally as important as our academics. They mould our future and help us in differentiating between right and wrong.

column11: Sexual/Domestic Violence and Identifying Workplace Harassment, Comprehensive Mental Health Awareness, Assessments & Resources, Conversations on Gender Identity & Sexuality, Financial Planning (basic concepts)
column31: I think the educational environment upheld these in some ways by policing what girls wore. For example, male students could walk around shirtless, play sports on the field shirtless etc but females were not allowed to do so and even sent home for wearing crop tops or skirts/shorts deemed too short. I don't think this is unique to my school at all, however, and would say that females were actually able to have more freedom compared to other schools in Mumbai. Other than that, generally, there was a judgmental environment towards female students expressing their sexuality but not towards male students.

column31: They went over some of these topics, mostly sex-ed, bullying and mental health. I think it was quite well covered considering we aren't that mature in school so some topics may not be understood. I think they should have had a more open student teacher environment where students would be comfortable talking to a grown up about these topics
column32: It will definitely make a difference
column33:
Within our cohort especially in Grade 11 and 12 there was a lot of conversation among peers. That really helped. But I think people who already have strong biases or opinions and don't respect women (directly or indirectly), they won't change as easily especially in senior grades. The key is to start the conversation at a young age. Middle and junior school teachers should be correcting young kids when they say something racist or sexist. We may not look back and remember these incidents where we were corrected but they have a huge impact on our subconscious opinions and actions. 

The open conversations really help with guys who are on the fence or understand the issue. It enables them to better understand it and actively participate in changing the situation. So it is helpful too!

column11: Sexual/Domestic Violence and Identifying Workplace Harassment, Comprehensive Mental Health Awareness, Assessments & Resources, Tackling Bullying & Identifying Toxic Environments, Comprehensive Sex Education beyond basic reproduction (safe sex, consent, pleasure, desire), Conversations on Gender Identity & Sexuality, Understanding Socio-Political landscape, Comprehensive understanding of Cyber Etiquettes, Crimes, Laws
column31: The school authorities were responsible for moral policing, including, dictating the length of the school uniform skirt and later, insisting that girls’ tops should cover their hips. The insistence on conforming to “safe behavior to prevent unwanted attention” was drummed into girls, rather than also confronting the boys with the consequences of their actions. We even had separate staircases for boys and girls between grade 8 and grade 10 to minimize conversations between the sexes. The biology curriculum during grades 11 and 12 covered aspects of sex education in some detail. I am not sure if the students who chose not to study Biology were ever exposed to that.
